====Painting and pigmentation====
=====Painting===== <!--THIS IS AN ENCYCLOPEDIA ARTICLE AND IS NOT INTENDED TO INCLUDE ENTIRE PASSAGES FROM BOOKS AND OTHER REFERENCES.
PLEASE ADD INFORMATION IN A "CONCISE" FORM WITHOUT QUOTING LARGE SEGMENTS OF TEXT, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE ARTICLE LENGTH WITHIN WIKIPEDIA LIMITS. PLEASE PROVIDE EQUAL WEIGHT FOR PRO/AGAINST AUTHENTICITY REFERENCES.
PLEASE SUPPORT EACH STATEMENT YOU ADD BY A SPECIFIC REFERENCE AND PROVIDE PAGE NUMBERS FOR REFERENCES. --> The technique used for producing the image is, according to Walter McCrone, described in a book about medieval painting published in 1847 by [[Charles Lock Eastlake]] (''Methods and Materials of Painting of the Great Schools and Masters''). Eastlake describes in the chapter "Practice of Painting Generally During the XIVth Century" a special technique of painting on linen using tempera paint, which produces images with unusual transparent features—which McCrone compares to the image on the shroud.<ref>Walter C. McCrone, ''Judgment day for the Shroud of Turin'', Amherst, N.Y., Prometheus Books, (1999) {{ISBN|1-57392-679-5}}</ref>
Pro-authenticity journals have declared this hypothesis to be unsound, stating that [[X-ray fluorescence]] examination, as well as [[infrared thermography]], did not reveal any pigment.<ref>G. Imbalzano, "Il linguaggio della Sindone", Sindon journal of the ''Centro Internazionale di Sindonologia'' of Turin, n.29, December 1980, pp. 13–23</ref><ref>Morris et al., "X-Ray fluorescence investigation of the Shroud of Turin", ''X-Ray Spectrometry'', vol. 9, n. 2, April 1980, pp. 40–47</ref><ref>A. D. Adler, "Aspetti fisico-chimici delle immagini sindoniche", ''Sindone, cento anni di ricerca'', Istituto Poligrafico e Zecca dello Stato, Libreria dello Stato, Roma 1998, pp. 165–184</ref> The non-paint origin has been further examined by [[Fourier transform]] of the image: common paintings show a directionality that is absent from the Turin Shroud.<ref>J. J. Lorre, D. J. Lynn, "Digital enhancement of images of the Shroud of Turin", in: ''Proceedings of the 1977 United States Conference of research on the Shroud of Turin'', Albuquerque 1977, Holy Shroud Guild, New York 1977</ref>
=====Acid pigmentation===== In 2009, Luigi Garlaschelli, professor of [[organic chemistry]] at the [[University of Pavia]], announced that he had made a full size reproduction of the Shroud of Turin using only medieval technologies. Garlaschelli placed a linen sheet over a volunteer and then rubbed it with an acidic pigment. The shroud was then aged in an oven before being washed to remove the pigment. He then added blood stains, scorches and water stains to replicate the original.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Garlaschelli |first1=L. |title=Life-size Reproduction of the Shroud of Turin and its Image |journal=Journal of Imaging Science and Technology |date=2010 |volume=54 |issue=4 |pages=040301 |doi=10.2352/J.ImagingSci.Technol.2010.54.4.040301}}</ref> But according to Giulio Fanti, professor of mechanical and thermic measurements at the [[University of Padua]], "the technique itself seems unable to produce an image having the most critical Turin Shroud image characteristics".<ref>Heimburger T., Fanti G., "[http://www.acheiropoietos.info/proceedings/HeimburgerWeb.pdf Scientific Comparison between the Turin Shroud and the First Handmade Whole Copy]", International Workshop on the Scientific Approach to the Acheiropoietos Images, 2010</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fanti |first1=G. |last2=Heimburger |first2=T. |date=2011 |title=Letter to the Editor Comments on 'Life-Size Reproduction of the Shroud of Turin and Its Image' by L. Garlaschelli |url= |journal=Journal of Imaging Science and Technology |volume=55 |issue=2 |page=020102 |doi=10.2352/j.imagingsci.technol.2011.55.2.020102}}</ref>
Garlaschelli's reproduction was featured in a 2010 National Geographic documentary. The technique used by Garlaschelli included the bas relief approach (described below) but only for the image of the face. The resultant image was visibly similar to the Turin Shroud, though lacking the uniformity and detail of the original.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/videos/remaking-the-shroud/ |title=Remaking the Shroud |date=22 January 2015 |website=Channel.nationalgeographic.com |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
====Medieval photography==== <!--THIS IS AN ENCYCLOPEDIA ARTICLE AND IS NOT INTENDED TO INCLUDE ENTIRE PASSAGES FROM BOOKS AND OTHER REFERENCES.
PLEASE ADD INFORMATION IN A "CONCISE" FORM WITHOUT QUOTING LARGE SEGMENTS OF TEXT, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE ARTICLE LENGTH WITHIN WIKIPEDIA LIMITS. PLEASE PROVIDE EQUAL WEIGHT FOR PRO/AGAINST AUTHENTICITY REFERENCES.
PLEASE SUPPORT EACH STATEMENT YOU ADD BY A SPECIFIC REFERENCE AND PROVIDE PAGE NUMBERS FOR REFERENCES. --> According to the art historian Nicholas Allen, the image on the shroud was formed by a photographic technique in the 13th century.<ref>[http://www.unisa.ac.za/Default.asp?Cmd=ViewContent&ContentID=7268 Nicholas P L Allen, ''Verification of the Nature and Causes of the Photo-negative Images on the Shroud of Lirey-Chambéry-Turin]''</ref> Allen maintains that techniques already available before the 14th century—e.g., as described in the [[Book of Optics]], which was at just that time translated from Arabic to Latin—were sufficient to produce primitive photographs, and that people familiar with these techniques would have been able to produce an image as found on the shroud. To demonstrate this, he successfully produced photographic images similar to the shroud using only techniques and materials available at the time the shroud was supposedly made. He described his results in his PhD thesis,<ref>Allen, Nicholas P. L. (1993) ''[https://researchspace.ukzn.ac.za/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10413/8589/Allen_Nicholas_P_L_1993.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y The methods and techniques employed in the manufacture of the Shroud of Turin].''</ref> in papers published in several science journals,<ref>Allen, Nicholas P. L. (1993) ''Is the Shroud of Turin the first recorded photograph? The South African Journal of Art History, 11 November, 23–32</ref><ref>Allen, Nicholas P. L. (1994)''A reappraisal of late thirteenth-century responses to the Shroud of Lirey-Chambéry-Turin: encolpia of the Eucharist, vera eikon or supreme relic?'' The Southern African Journal of Medieval and Renaissance Studies, 4 (1), 62–94</ref> and in a book.<ref>Allen, Nicholas P. L. (1998)''The Turin Shroud and the Crystal Lens.'' Empowerment Technologies Pty. Ltd., – Port Elizabeth, South Africa</ref> [[Silver bromide]] is believed by some to have been used for making the Shroud of Turin as it is widely used in photographic films.<ref name="Hamilton1974">{{cite journal |last=Hamilton |first=J.F. |title=Physical Properties of Silver Halide Microcrystals |journal=Photographic Science and Engineering |date=1974 |volume=18 |issue=5 |pages=493–500}}</ref>
====Dust-transfer technique==== <!--THIS IS AN ENCYCLOPEDIA ARTICLE AND IS NOT INTENDED TO INCLUDE ENTIRE PASSAGES FROM BOOKS AND OTHER REFERENCES.
PLEASE ADD INFORMATION IN A "CONCISE" FORM WITHOUT QUOTING LARGE SEGMENTS OF TEXT, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE ARTICLE LENGTH WITHIN WIKIPEDIA LIMITS. PLEASE PROVIDE EQUAL WEIGHT FOR PRO/AGAINST AUTHENTICITY REFERENCES.
PLEASE SUPPORT EACH STATEMENT YOU ADD BY A SPECIFIC REFERENCE AND PROVIDE PAGE NUMBERS FOR REFERENCES. --> Scientists Emily Craig and Randall Bresee have attempted to recreate the likenesses of the shroud through the dust-transfer technique, which could have been done by medieval arts. They first did a carbon-dust drawing of a Jesus-like face (using collagen dust) on a newsprint made from wood pulp (which is similar to 13th- and 14th-century paper). They next placed the drawing on a table and covered it with a piece of linen. They then pressed the linen against the newsprint by firmly rubbing with the flat side of a wooden spoon. By doing this they managed to create a reddish-brown image with a lifelike positive likeness of a person, a three-dimensional image and no sign of brush strokes.<ref>Craig, Emily A, Bresee, Randal R, "Image Formation and the Shroud of Turin", ''Journal of Imaging Science and Technology'', Volume 34, Number 1, 1994</ref> However, according to Fanti and Moroni, this does not reproduce many special features of the Shroud at microscopic level.<ref name=Fanti2002/>
====Bas-relief==== <!--THIS IS AN ENCYCLOPEDIA ARTICLE AND IS NOT INTENDED TO INCLUDE ENTIRE PASSAGES FROM BOOKS AND OTHER REFERENCES.
PLEASE ADD INFORMATION IN A "CONCISE" FORM WITHOUT QUOTING LARGE SEGMENTS OF TEXT, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE ARTICLE LENGTH WITHIN WIKIPEDIA LIMITS. PLEASE PROVIDE EQUAL WEIGHT FOR PRO/AGAINST AUTHENTICITY REFERENCES.
PLEASE SUPPORT EACH STATEMENT YOU ADD BY A SPECIFIC REFERENCE AND PROVIDE PAGE NUMBERS FOR REFERENCES. --> Another hypothesis suggests that the Shroud may have been formed using a [[bas-relief]] sculpture. Researcher Jacques di Costanzo, noting that the Shroud image seems to have a three-dimensional quality, suggested that perhaps the image was formed using a three-dimensional object, such as a sculpture. While wrapping a cloth around a life-sized statue would result in a distorted image, placing a cloth over a bas-relief would result in an image like the one seen on the shroud. To demonstrate the plausibility of his hypothesis, Costanzo constructed a bas-relief of a Jesus-like face and draped wet linen over the bas-relief. After the linen dried, he dabbed it with a mixture of [[ferric oxide]] and [[gelatine]]. The result was an image similar to that of the Shroud. The imprinted image turned out to be wash-resistant, impervious to temperatures of {{convert |250 |C |abbr=on}} and was undamaged by exposure to a range of harsh chemicals, including bisulphite which, without the gelatine, would normally have degraded ferric oxide to the compound ferrous oxide.<ref name="'Ingham">{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Ingham |title=Turin Shroud Confirmed as Fake |date=21 June 2005 |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |url=http://www.physorg.com/news4652.html |work=Physorg.com |pages=|access-date=17 February 2008}}</ref> Similar results have been obtained by Nickell.
Instead of painting, it has been suggested that the bas-relief could also be heated and used to scorch an image onto the cloth. However researcher Thibault Heimburger performed some experiments with the scorching of linen, and found that a scorch mark is only produced by direct contact with the hot object – thus producing an all-or-nothing discoloration with no graduation of color as is found in the shroud.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shroudofturin.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/scorch-paper-en.pdf |title=The Turin Shroud Body Image: The Scorch Hypothesis Revisited |author=Thibault Heimburger |publisher= |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
According to Fanti and Moroni, after comparing the [[Color histogram|histogram]]s of 256 different grey levels, it was found that the image obtained with a bas-relief has grey values included between 60 and 256 levels, but it is much contrasted with wide areas of white saturation (levels included between 245 and 256) and lacks of intermediate grey levels (levels included between 160 and 200). The face image on the Shroud instead has grey tonalities that vary in the same values field (between 60 and 256), but the white saturation is much less marked and the histogram is practically flat in correspondence of the intermediate grey levels (levels included between 160 and 200).<ref name=Fanti2002>{{cite journal |last1=Fanti |first1=G. |last2=Moroni |first2=M. |title=Comparison of Luminance Between Face of Turin Shroud Man and Experimental Results |journal=Journal of Imaging Science and Technology |date=1 March 2002 |volume=46 |issue=2 |pages=142–154 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ist/jist/2002/00000046/00000002/art00009#expand/collapse |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>
====Maillard reaction==== <!--THIS IS AN ENCYCLOPEDIA ARTICLE AND IS NOT INTENDED TO INCLUDE ENTIRE PASSAGES FROM BOOKS AND OTHER REFERENCES.
PLEASE ADD INFORMATION IN A "CONCISE" FORM WITHOUT QUOTING LARGE SEGMENTS OF TEXT, IN ORDER TO KEEP THE ARTICLE LENGTH WITHIN WIKIPEDIA LIMITS. PLEASE PROVIDE EQUAL WEIGHT FOR PRO/AGAINST AUTHENTICITY REFERENCES.
PLEASE SUPPORT EACH STATEMENT YOU ADD BY A SPECIFIC REFERENCE AND PROVIDE PAGE NUMBERS FOR REFERENCES. --> The [[Maillard reaction]] is a form of non-enzymatic browning involving an amino acid and a reducing sugar. The [[cellulose]] fibers of the shroud are coated with a thin [[carbohydrate]] layer of [[starch]] fractions, various [[sugars]], and other impurities. In a paper entitled "The Shroud of Turin: an amino-carbonyl reaction may explain the image formation,"<ref>Rogers, R.N. and Arnoldi, A.: "The Shroud of Turin: an amino-carbonyl reaction (Maillard reaction) may explain the image formation", ''Melanoidins in Food and Health'', Volume 4, Office for Official Publications of the European Communities, Luxembourg, 2003, pp. 106–113, {{ISBN|92-894-5724-4}}</ref> [[Raymond N. Rogers|Raymond Rogers]] and Anna Arnoldi propose that [[amine]]s from a recently deceased human body may have undergone Maillard reactions with this carbohydrate layer within a reasonable period of time, before liquid [[decomposition]] products stained or damaged the cloth. The gases produced by a dead body are extremely reactive chemically and within a few hours, in an environment such as a tomb, a body starts to produce heavier amines in its tissues such as [[putrescine]] and [[cadaverine]]. However the potential source for amines required for the reaction is a decomposing body,<ref name=Rogers2008/>{{rp|100}} and no signs of decomposition have been found on the Shroud.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shroudcentersocal.com/ |format= |title=Features of the Center |publisher=Shroud Center of Southern California |access-date=27 March 2010}}</ref> Rogers also notes that their tests revealed that there were no proteins or bodily fluids on the image areas.<ref name=Rogers2008/>{{rp|38}} Also, the image resolution and the uniform coloration of the linen resolution seem to be incompatible with a mechanism involving diffusion.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |last1=Fanti |first1=G. |last2=Botella |first2=J. A. |last3=Di Lazzaro |first3=P. |last4=Heimburger |first4=T. |last5=Schneider |first5=R. |last6=Svensson |first6=N. |title=Microscopic and Macroscopic Characteristics of the Shroud of Turin Image Superficiality |journal=Journal of Imaging Science and Technology |date=2010 |volume=54 |issue=4 |pages=040201 |doi=10.2352/J.ImagingSci.Technol.2010.54.4.040201}}</ref>
Alan A. Mills argued that the image was formed by the chemical reaction [[auto-oxidation]]. He noted that the image corresponds to what would have been produced by a volatile chemical if the intensity of the color change were inversely proportional to the distance from the body of a loosely draped cloth.<ref>Alan A. Mills, "Image formation on the Shroud of Turin", in ''Interdisciplinary Science Reviews'', 1995, vol. 20 No. 4, pp. 319–326.</ref>
====Energy source==== Since 1930<ref>N. Noguier de Malijay, ''La Santa Sindone di Torino'', Libreria del S. Cuore, Torino, 1930</ref> several researchers (J. Jackson, G. Fanti, T. Trenn, T. Phillips, J.-B. Rinaudo and others) endorsed the flash-like irradiation hypothesis. It was suggested that the relatively high definition of the image details can be obtained through the energy source (specifically, [[proton]]ic) acting from inside.<ref name="Jacksonet">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=John P. |last2=Jumper |first2=Eric J. |last3=Ercoline |first3=William R. |title=Correlation of image intensity on the Turin Shroud with the 3-D structure of a human body shape |journal=Applied Optics |date=15 July 1984 |volume=23 |issue=14 |pages=2244 |doi=10.1364/AO.23.002244|pmid=18212985 }}</ref> The Russian researcher Alexander Belyakov proposed an intense, but short flashlight source, which lasted some hundredths of a second.<ref>A. Belyakov, "Prospettive di ricerca in Russia sulla Sindone di Torino", ''Atti del convegno di San Felice Circeo (LT)'' 24–25 agosto 1996, pp. 19–24</ref> Some other authors suggest the X-radiation<ref>G. Carter, "Formation of the Image on the Shroud of Turin", ''[[American Chemical Society]] Volume on Archaeological Chemistry'', 1983</ref> or a burst of directional [[ultraviolet radiation]] may have played a role in the formation of the Shroud image.<ref name=Baldacchini2008>{{cite journal |last1=Baldacchini |first1=G. |last2=Lazzaro |first2=P. Di |last3=Murra |first3=D. |last4=Fanti |first4=G. |date=2008 |title=Coloring linens with excimer lasers to simulate the body image of the Turin Shroud |url=http://www.opticsinfobase.org/ao/abstract.cfm?URI=ao-47-9-1278 |journal=Applied Optics |volume=47 |issue= 9|pages=1278–1285 |doi=10.1364/ao.47.001278}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last1=Di Lazzaro |first1=P. |title=XVII International Symposium on Gas Flow, Chemical Lasers, and High-Power Lasers |last2=Baldacchini |first2=G. |last3=Fanti |first3=G. |last4=Murra |first4=D. |last5=Santoni |first5=A. |date=22 April 2009 |volume=7131 |pages=71311R–71311R–6 |doi=10.1117/12.816826 |chapter-url=http://holyshroudguild.org/media/A$20PHYSICAL$20HYPOTHESIS$20ON$20THE$20ORIGIN$20OF$20THE$20BODY$20IMAGE$20EMBEDDED$20INTO$20THE$20TURIN$20SHROUD.pdf|chapter=Colouring fabrics with excimer lasers to simulate encoded images: the case of the Shroud of Turin |series=XVII International Symposium on Gas Flow, Chemical Lasers, and High-Power Lasers }}</ref> From the image characteristics, several researchers have theorized that the radiant source was prevalently vertical. These theories do not include the scientific discussion of a method by which the energy could have been produced.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
=====Corona discharge===== During restoration in 2002, the back of the cloth was photographed and scanned for the first time. Giulio Fanti, a scientist at the [[University of Padua]], wrote an article on this subject with colleagues in 2005 that envisages electrostatic [[corona discharge]] as the probable mechanism to produce the images of the body in the Shroud.<ref>G. Fanti, F. Lattarulo, O. Scheuermann, "[http://www.dii.unipd.it/-giulio.fanti/research/Sindone/corona.pdf Body Image Formation Hypotheses Based on Corona Discharge] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022011611/https://www.dii.unipd.it/-giulio.fanti/research/Sindone/corona.pdf |date=22 October 2016 }}", 2005</ref> Congruent with that mechanism, they also describe an image on the reverse side of the fabric, much fainter than that on the front view of the body, consisting primarily of the face and perhaps hands. As with the front picture, it is entirely superficial, with coloration limited to the carbohydrate layer. The images correspond to, and are in registration with, those on the other side of the cloth. No image is detectable in the reverse side of the dorsal view of the body.
Raymond Rogers criticized the theory, saying: "It is clear that a corona discharge (plasma) in air will cause easily observable changes in a linen sample. No such effects can be observed in image fibers from the Shroud of Turin. Corona discharges and/or plasmas made no contribution to image formation."<ref name=Rogers2008>{{cite book |last1=Rogers |first1=Raymond N. |title=A Chemist's Perspective On The Shroud of Turin |date=July 2008 |publisher=[[Lulu (company)|Lulu Press, Inc.]] |isbn=9780615239286 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p-n84sc4ayYC&pg=PA83}}</ref>{{rp|83}}
In December 2011, Fanti published a critical compendium of the major hypotheses regarding the formation of the body image on the shroud. He stated that "none of them can completely explain the mysterious image". Fanti then considered corona discharge as the most probable hypothesis regarding the formation of the body image.<ref name="Fanti1211">{{cite journal |last1=Fanti |first1=G. |date=2011 |title=Hypotheses Regarding the Formation of the Body Image: A Critical Compendium [Abstract] |doi=10.2352/J.ImagingSci.Technol.2011.55.6.060507 |journal=[[The Journal of Imaging Science and Technology]] |volume=55 |issue=6 |page=060507}}</ref> He stated that it would be impossible to reproduce all the characteristics of the image in a laboratory because the energy source required would be too high.<ref name=Fanti2010Corona>{{cite journal |last1=Fanti |first1=G. |date=2010 |title=Can a Corona Discharge Explain the Body Image of the Turin Shroud? |url=http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=JIMTE6000054000002020508000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=Yes&ref=no |journal=J. Imaging Sci. Technol |volume=54 |issue=2 |page=020508 |doi=10.2352/j.imagingsci.technol.2010.54.2.020508}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA" /> Fanti has restated the radiation theories in a 2013 book.<ref name="Squires_The Daily Telegraph">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/9958678/Turin-Shroud-is-not-a-medieval-forgery.html |date=28 March 2013 |title=Turin Shroud 'is not a medieval forgery' |last=Squires |first=Nick |work=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=28 March 2013}}</ref>
=====Ultraviolet radiation===== In December 2011 scientists at Italy's National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Sustainable Development [[ENEA (Italy)|ENEA]] deduced from the STURP results that the color of the Shroud image is the result of an accelerated aging process of the linen, similar to the yellowing of the paper of ancient books. They demonstrated that the photochemical reactions caused by exposing linen to [[ultraviolet]] light could reproduce the main characteristics of the Shroud image, such as the shallowness of the coloration and the gradient of the color, which are not reproducible by other means. When subsequently illuminated with a UV lamp, the irradiated linen fabrics behaved like the linen of the Shroud. They also determined that UV radiation changes the crystalline structure of cellulose in a similar manner as aging and long-duration background radiation.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Paolo|last1=Di Lazzaro|first2=Daniele|last2=Murra|first3=Antonino|last3=Santoni|first4=Enrico|last4=Nichelatti|url=http://www.enea.it/it/produzione-scientifica/EAI/anno-2012/knowledge-diagnostics-and-preservation-of-cultural-heritage/the-conservation-of-the-shroud-of-turin-optical-studies |title=The Conservation of the Shroud of Turin: Optical Studies |accessdate=2013-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416225452/http://www.enea.it/it/produzione-scientifica/EAI/anno-2012/knowledge-diagnostics-and-preservation-of-cultural-heritage/the-conservation-of-the-shroud-of-turin-optical-studies |archivedate=16 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=COLORAZIONE SIMIL–SINDONICA DI TESSUTI DI LINO TRAMITE RADIAZIONE NEL LONTANO ULTRAVIOLETTO |issn=0393-3016 |url=http://opac.bologna.enea.it:8991/RT/2011/2011_14_ENEA.pdf}}</ref>
Paolo Di Lazzaro, the lead researcher, indicated in an e-mail interview that "... it appears unlikely a forger may have done this image with technologies available in the Middle Ages or earlier", but their study does not mean the Shroud image was created by the flash of a miraculous resurrection, contrary to how the story was presented in the media, especially on the Web.<ref name="lazzaro">{{cite web |url=http://cosmiclog.nbcnews.com/_news/2011/12/22/9636065-was-holy-shroud-created-in-a-flash-italian-researchers-resurrect-claim |title=Was Holy Shroud created in a flash? Italian researchers resurrect claim |last=Boyle |first=Alan |website=Cosmic Log |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=23 December 2011 |access-date=29 June 2014}}</ref> Professional skeptic [[Joe Nickell]] states that the latest findings are nothing new despite being "dressed up in high-tech tests", and that they don't prove much of anything.<ref name="lazzaro" />
=====Burial ointments===== In November 2011, F. Curciarello ''et al.'' published a paper that analyzed the abrupt changes in the yellowed [[fibril]] density values on the Shroud image. They concluded that the rapid changes in the body image intensity are not anomalies in the manufacturing process of the linen but that they can be explained with the presence of aromas or burial ointments.<ref name="Fazio11">{{cite journal |last1=Curciarello |first1=F. |last2=De Leo |first2=V. |last3=Fazio |first3=G. |last4=Mandaglio |first4=G. |title=The abrupt changes in the yellowed fibril density in the Linen of Turin |journal=Radiation Effects and Defects in Solids |date=March 2012 |volume=167 |issue=3 |pages=224–228 |doi=10.1080/10420150.2011.629320}}</ref> However, their work leaves the existence of an energy source for the image an open question.<ref name="Fazio11" />
====Minimal Facts approach==== A 2013 study published in a theological journal followed a "Minimal Facts approach" to determine which hypothesis relating to the image formation process "is the most likely". The study concluded "that the probability of the Shroud of Turin being the real shroud of Jesus of Nazareth is very high".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Casabianca |first1=Tristan |title=The Shroud of Turin: A Historiographical Approach |journal=The Heythrop Journal |date=May 2013 |volume=54 |issue=3 |pages=414–423 |doi=10.1111/heyj.12014}}</ref>

[[image:Icelandic tephra.JPG|250px|thumb|right|Tephra horizons in south-central [[Iceland]]. The thick and light coloured layer at the height of the [[volcanologist]]'s hands is [[rhyolitic]] [[tephra]] from [[Hekla]].]]
[[Image:tephrochronology iceland.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Geologist explaining the importance of tephochronology to students on field in [[Iceland]].]] '''Tephrochronology''' is a [[Geochronology|geochronological]] technique that uses discrete layers of [[tephra]]—volcanic ash from a single eruption—to create a chronological framework in which [[Paleoenviroment|paleoenvironmental]] or [[Archaeology|archaeological]] records can be placed. Such an established event provides a "tephra horizon". The premise of the technique is that each volcanic event produces ash with a unique chemical "fingerprint" that allows the deposit to be identified across the area affected by fallout. Thus, once the volcanic event has been independently dated, the tephra horizon will act as time marker.
The main advantages of the technique are that the [[volcanic ash]] layers can be relatively easily identified in many sediments and that the [[tephra layer]]s are deposited relatively instantaneously over a wide spatial area. This means they provide accurate temporal marker layers which can be used to verify or corroborate other dating techniques, linking sequences widely separated by location into a unified chronology that correlates climatic sequences and events.
Tephrochronology requires accurate geochemical fingerprinting (usually via an [[electron microprobe]]).<ref>Smith & Westgate (1969)</ref> An important recent advance is the use of LA-ICP-MS (i.e. [[laser ablation]] [[ICP-MS]]) to measure trace-element abundances in individual tephra shards.<ref>Pearce et al. (2002)</ref> One problem in tephrochronology is that tephra chemistry can become altered over time, at least for basaltic tephras.<ref>Pollard et al. (2003)</ref>
Early tephra horizons were identified with the [[Saksunarvatn tephra]] (Icelandic origin, {{circa|10.2}} [[Calibration of radiocarbon dates|cal.]] [[Year#SI prefix multipliers|ka]] BP), forming a horizon in the late [[Boreal (period)|Pre-Boreal]] of Northern Europe, the Vedde ash (also Icelandic in origin, c. 12.0 cal. ka BP) and the [[Laacher See]] tephra (in the [[Eifel]] volcanic field, c. 12.9 cal. ka BP). Major volcanoes which have been used in tephrochronological studies include [[Vesuvius]], [[Hekla]] and [[Santorini]]. Minor volcanic events may also leave their fingerprint in the geological record: [[Hayes Volcano]] is responsible for a series of six major [[tephra layer]]s in the Cook Inlet region of Alaska. Tephra horizons provide a synchronous check against which to correlate the palaeoclimatic reconstructions that are obtained from terrestrial records, like fossil pollen studies ([[palynology]]), from [[varve]]s in lake sediments or from marine deposits and [[Ice core|ice-core records]], and to extend the limits of [[carbon-14 dating]].
A pioneer in the use of tephra layers as [[marker horizon]]s to establish chronology was [[Sigurdur Thorarinsson]], who began by studying the layers he found in his native Iceland.<ref>Alloway et al. (2007)</ref> Since the late 1990s, techniques developed by Chris S. M. Turney ([[QUB]], Belfast; now [[University of Exeter]]) and others for extracting tephra horizons invisible to the naked eye ("cryptotephra")<ref name="Turneyet">Turney et al. (1997)</ref> have revolutionised the application of tephrochronology. This technique relies upon the difference between the specific gravity of the microtephra shards and the host sediment matrix. It has led to the first discovery of the Vedde ash on the mainland of Britain, in Sweden, in the [[Netherlands]], in the Swiss Lake [[Soppensee]] and in two sites on the [[Karelian Isthmus]] of Baltic Russia. It has also revealed previously undetected ash layers, such as the Borrobol Tephra first discovered in northern [[Scotland]], dated to c. 14.4 cal. ka BP,<ref name="Turneyet" /> the microtephra horizons of equivalent geochemistry from southern [[Sweden]], dated at 13,900 Cariaco varve yrs BP<ref>Davies (2004)</ref> and from northwest Scotland, dated at 13.6 cal. ka BP.<ref>Ranner et al. (2005)</ref>

== 8th century == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[718]] || || The [[Visigoths|Visigothic]] [[nobility|nobleman]] [[Pelagius of Asturias]] rebelled against the [[Umayyad Caliphate]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[722]] || Summer || ''[[Battle of Covadonga]]'': Forces loyal to [[Pelagius of Asturias|Pelagius]] decimated an [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] army sent to reconquer them in a valley in the [[Picos de Europa]]. |- | || [[Pelagius of Asturias|Pelagius]] was elected ''princeps'' of the independent [[Kingdom of Asturias]] with his capital at [[Cangas de Onís]]. |- | [[737]] || || [[Pelagius of Asturias|Pelagius]] died. He was succeeded as ''princeps'' by his son [[Favila of Asturias]]. |- | [[739]] || || [[Favila of Asturias|Favila]] was killed by a bear while hunting. He was succeeded by his brother-in-law [[Alfonso I of Asturias|Alfonso I the Catholic of Asturias]], the son of [[Peter of Cantabria]], the [[duke]] of [[Duchy of Cantabria|Cantabria]]. |- | [[740]] || || [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] conquered and annexed [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]]. |- | [[757]] || || [[Alfonso I of Asturias|Alfonso the Catholic]] died. He was succeeded as [[king]] by his son [[Fruela I of Asturias|Fruela I the Cruel of Asturias]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[768]] || 14 January || [[Fruela I of Asturias|Fruela]] was assassinated. |- | || [[Fruela I of Asturias|Fruela's]] cousin [[Aurelius of Asturias]] was crowned [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. |- | [[774]] || || [[Aurelius of Asturias|Aurelius]] died. He was succeeded by his cousin-in-law, [[Silo of Asturias]], husband of [[Alfonso I of Asturias|Alfonso the Catholic's]] daughter [[Adosinda]]. Silo established his capital at [[Pravia]]. |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[783]] || || [[Silo of Asturias|Silo]] died. |- | || [[Adosinda]] engineered the election of her nephew [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso II the Chaste of Asturias]], son of [[Fruela I of Asturias|Fruela]], as [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. |- | || A coalition of nobles elected [[Alfonso I of Asturias|Alfonso the Catholic's]] illegitimate son [[Mauregatus of Asturias]] [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso the Chaste]] fled to [[Álava]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[789]] || || [[Mauregatus of Asturias|Mauregatus]] died. |- | || [[Aurelius of Asturias|Aurelius's]] brother [[Bermudo I of Asturias|Bermudo I the Deacon, the Monk of Asturias]] was elected [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[791]] || || ''[[Battle of the Burbia River]]'': An [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] force attacked a [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] army near [[Villafranca del Bierzo]] on its return to Córdoba and was defeated. |- | || [[Bermudo I of Asturias|Bermudo]] abdicated the throne. |- | 14 September || [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso the Chaste]] was crowned [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] in [[Toledo, Spain]]. |- | || [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso the Chaste]] established his capital at [[Oviedo]]. |- | [[794]] || || ''[[Battle of Lutos]]'': A [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] army returning from a scorched earth campaign in modern [[Álava]] was wiped out by an [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] force. |- | [[795]] || 18 September || ''[[Battle of Las Babias]]'': [[Emirate of Córdoba|Córdoba]] attacked and routed an [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] force near [[Astorga, Spain]]. |} == 9th century == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[816]] || || ''[[Battle of Pancorbo (816)]]'': [[Emirate of Córdoba|Córdoba]] slaughtered a [[Basques|Basque]]-[[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] force defending the Basque homeland in the [[Pyrenees]] at [[Pancorbo]]. |- | [[824]] || || ''[[Battle of Roncevaux Pass (824)]]'': A combined force of [[Basques]] and the [[Banu Qasi]], both [[vassal]]s of the [[emirate of Córdoba]], defeated a [[Carolingian Empire|Carolingian]] military expedition in the [[Roncevaux Pass]]. The Basque [[tribal chief|chieftain]] [[Íñigo Arista of Pamplona]] was crowned [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] at [[Pamplona]]. |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[842]] || || [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso the Chaste]] died. |- | || The [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] [[nobility]] elected [[Nepotian of Asturias]], a relative of [[Alfonso II of Asturias|Alfonso the Chaste]], [[king]]. |- | || ''[[Battle of the Bridge of Cornellana]]'': Forces loyal to [[Bermudo I of Asturias|Bermudo's]] son [[Ramiro I of Asturias]] defeated [[Nepotian of Asturias|Nepotian]] in modern [[Salas, Asturias]]. |- | [[850]] || 1 February || [[Ramiro I of Asturias|Ramiro]] died. He was buried in the [[Pantheon of Asturian Kings]] in [[Oviedo]]. His son [[Ordoño I of Asturias]] succeeded him as [[king]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[851]] || || ''[[Battle of Albelda (851)]]'': [[Ordoño I of Asturias|Ordoño]] suppressed a [[Basques|Basque]] revolt in northeastern [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] and expelled an opportunistic [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] invasion near [[Albelda]]. |- | || [[Íñigo Arista of Pamplona|Íñigo]] died. He was succeeded as [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] by his son [[García Íñiguez of Pamplona]]. |- | [[852]] || || ''[[Battle of Guadalacete]]'': [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Pamplonan]] forces arriving in support of a revolt of the people of [[Toledo, Spain]] were routed by a [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] army. |- | [[859]] || || [[Vikings]] captured [[García Íñiguez of Pamplona|García]] and extorted a ransom of some seventy thousand [[gold dinar]]s from [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] for his return. |- | [[860]] || || [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] forces captured [[García Íñiguez of Pamplona|García's]] son and heir [[Fortún Garcés of Pamplona|Fortún Garcés the One-Eyed, the Monk of Pamplona]] in [[Milagro, Navarre]]. |- | [[862]] || || An eastern [[march (territorial entity)|march]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] was created the county of Castile under [[count]] [[Rodrigo of Castile]]. |- | [[865]] || 9 August || ''[[Battle of the Morcuera]]'': [[Emirate of Córdoba|Córdoba]] attacked [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]], forcing the retreat of Asturian forces and their Castilian allies along the valley of the [[Ebro]]. |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[866]] || 27 May || [[Ordoño I of Asturias|Ordoño]] died. He was succeeded by his eldest son [[Alfonso III of Asturias|Alfonso III the Great of Asturias]]. |- | || [[Fruela (usurper)|Fruela]] seized the throne of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] and forced [[Alfonso III of Asturias|Alfonso the Great]] to flee to Castile. |- | || [[Fruela (usurper)|Fruela]] was assassinated in [[Oviedo]]. |- | [[868]] || || [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] conquered [[Porto]]. [[Vímara Peres]] was created [[count]] of [[County of Portugal|Portugal]]. |- | [[870]] || || [[García Íñiguez of Pamplona|García]] died. [[García Jiménez of Pamplona]] took power as [[regent]], García's son and heir [[Fortún Garcés of Pamplona|Fortún Garcés]] remaining in captivity in [[Emirate of Córdoba|Córdoba]]. |- | [[873]] || 5 November || [[Rodrigo of Castile|Rodrigo]] died. He was succeeded as [[count]] of Castile by his son [[Diego Rodríguez Porcelos]]. |- | [[878]] || || [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] conquered [[Coimbra]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[882]] || || ''[[First Battle of Cellorigo]]'': [[Vela Jiménez]], [[count]] of the [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] [[county of Álava]], repelled an attempted conquest by the [[Emirate of Córdoba]] of an important mountain pass at [[Cellorigo]]. |- | || [[Fortún Garcés of Pamplona|Fortún Garcés]] was returned to rule in [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]. |- | [[883]] || || ''[[Second Battle of Cellorigo]]'': [[Vela Jiménez]] repelled an attempted conquest by the [[Emirate of Córdoba]] of an important mountain pass at [[Cellorigo]]. |- | [[885]] || 31 January || [[Diego Rodríguez Porcelos|Rodríguez]] died. |} == 10th century == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[901]] || July || ''[[Day of Zamora]]'': The [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturian]] defenders of [[Zamora, Spain]] dealt heavy casualties to a [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] force attempting to conquer it. The heads of the besiegers were displayed on the city walls. |- | [[905]] || || The [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] [[nobility]] removed [[Fortún Garcés of Pamplona|Fortún Garcés]] from the throne, placing [[Sancho I of Pamplona]] there in his stead. |- | [[910]] || 20 December || [[Alfonso III of Asturias|Alfonso the Great]] died and was buried at [[Oviedo Cathedral]]. His kingdom was divided among his three sons, with his eldest, [[García I of León]], receiving [[Kingdom of León|León]], [[Ordoño II of León]] receiving [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]], and [[Fruela II of Asturias]] receiving a rump [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] including Castile. |- | [[914]] || 19 January || [[García I of León|García I]] died. His lands passed to [[Ordoño II of León|Ordoño II]]. |- | [[917]] || || ''[[Battle of San Esteban de Gormaz (917)]]'': [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] forces broke a [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] siege of [[San Esteban de Gormaz]]. |- | [[920]] || 26 July || ''[[Battle of Valdejunquera]]'': A [[Emirate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] army invading Castile routed a joint [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]]-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] force at Valdejunquera, probably between modern [[Estella-Lizarra]] and [[Pamplona]], forcing the abandonment by León of [[Clunia]]. |- | [[922]] || || [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] defeated [[Galindo Aznárez II]], [[count]] of the [[County of Aragon]], in battle and forced him into [[vassal]]age. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[924]] || June || [[Ordoño II of León|Ordoño II]] died. |- | || The [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] nobility elected [[Fruela II of Asturias|Fruela II]] [[king]] of León. |- | rowspan="6" valign="top" | [[925]] || July || [[Fruela II of Asturias|Fruela II]] died, possibly from leprosy. His will named his son [[Alfonso Fróilaz]] his successor. [[Ordoño II of León|Ordoño II's]] sons [[Sancho Ordóñez]], [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso IV the Monk of León]] and [[Ramiro II of León]] did not recognize Fróilaz's succession, however, leaving him in ''de facto'' authority only in [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]]. |- | || [[Fruela II of Asturias|Fruela II's]] younger brother, a Ramiro, married his widow Urraca bint Abd Allah and claimed the royal title. |- | || [[Sancho Ordóñez|Ordóñez]], [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso the Monk]] and [[Ramiro II of León|Ramiro II]] forced [[Alfonso Fróilaz|Fróilaz]] into exile in the eastern [[march (territorial entity)|marches]] of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]]. |- | || [[Sancho Ordóñez|Ordóñez]] seized [[León, Spain]]. |- | || [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso the Monk]], with the support of [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] and the [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] nobility, expelled [[Sancho Ordóñez|Ordóñez]] from [[León, Spain]]. |- | 10 December || [[Sancho I of Pamplona|Sancho I]] died. He was succeeded by his young son [[García Sánchez I of Pamplona]] with his brother [[Jimeno Garcés of Pamplona]] acting as regent. |- | [[926]] || || [[Sancho Ordóñez|Ordóñez]] was crowned ''princeps'' of [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]]. |- | [[929]] || 16 August || [[Sancho Ordóñez|Ordóñez]] died. His territory passed to [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso the Monk]]. |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[931]] || || [[Fernán González of Castile]] became [[count]] of Castile. |- | || [[Álvaro Herraméliz]], [[count]] of Lantarón and [[County of Álava|Álava]], died. [[Fernán González of Castile|Fernán González]] inherited his territories and united them with Castile. |- | 29 May || [[Jimeno Garcés of Pamplona|Jimeno Garcés]] died. |- | || [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso the Monk]] was forced to abdicate the rule of [[Kingdom of León|León]] and [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]] to his brother [[Ramiro II of León|Ramiro II]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[939]] || 19 July || ''[[Battle of Simancas]]'': A battle began near [[Simancas]] which would see a joint [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]]-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] force repel an attempted [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] conquest of the lands around the [[Douro]]. |- | 5 August || ''[[Battle of Alhandic]]'': [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Cordoban]] forces conquered the [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] city of [[Zamora, Spain]] with great cost in lives to both sides. |- | [[951]] || 1 January || [[Ramiro II of León|Ramiro II]] died and was buried in the [[Basílica de San Isidoro, León]]. He was succeeded by his son [[Ordoño III of León]]. |- | [[956]] || || [[Ordoño III of León|Ordoño III]] died in [[Zamora, Spain]]. He was succeeded by his half-brother [[Sancho I of León|Sancho I the Fat of León]]. |- | [[958]] || || The [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]] [[nobility]], led by [[Fernán González of Castile|Fernán González]], deposed [[Sancho I of León|Sancho the Fat]] in favor of [[Alfonso IV of León|Alfonso the Monk's]] son [[Ordoño IV of León|Ordoño IV the Wicked, the Bad of León]]. |- | [[960]] || || [[Sancho I of León|Sancho the Fat]] was restored to the throne of [[Kingdom of León|León]] with the support of [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] and [[Caliphate of Córdoba|Córdoba]]. |- | [[966]] || || [[Sancho I of León|Sancho the Fat]] was poisoned by [[count]] [[Gonzalo Menéndez]] of [[County of Portugal|Portugal]] and buried in the [[Basílica de San Isidoro, León]]. He was succeeded by his young son [[Ramiro III of León]], with the latter's aunt [[Elvira Ramírez]] and mother [[Teresa Ansúrez]] ruling as regents. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[970]] || 22 February || [[García Sánchez I of Pamplona|García Sánchez I]] died. He was succeeded by his eldest son [[Sancho II of Pamplona]]. A small territory around [[Viguera]] he willed to another son as the [[Kingdom of Viguera]]. |- | || [[Fernán González of Castile|Fernán González]] died. {{nihongo|'''Urasoe'''|浦添市|Urasoe-shi|[[Okinawan language|Okinawan]]: ''Urashii''}} is a [[Cities of Japan|city]] located in [[Okinawa Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. The neighboring municipalities are [[Naha]] to the south, [[Ginowan]] to the north, and [[Nishihara, Okinawa|Nishihara]] to the east.
As of November 2012, the city has an estimated [[population]] of 113,718 and a [[population density]] of 5,956.9 persons per km<sup>2</sup>. The total area is 19.09 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="pop"/>
[[United States Marine Corps]] base [[Camp Kinser]] is located on the city's coast.
==Etymology== The name "Urasoe" is made up of two [[kanji]] characters. The first, {{linktext|浦}}, means "a coastal area", and the second, {{linktext|添}}, means "ruling" or "uniting". The name is a reference to "ruling over many areas".<ref name="guide" /><ref name="n" />
==Geography== Urasoe sits to the south of [[Okinawa Island]]. Urasoe is rugged and hilly to the east, and the city slopes gently to the [[East China Sea]] in the west.<ref name="n" /> Urasoe, while formerly agricultural, has become heavily urbanized due to its proximity to the prefectural capital of [[Naha]].<ref name="guide"/><ref name="n" />
===Neighboring municipalities=== *[[Naha, Okinawa|Naha]] *[[Ginowan, Okinawa|Ginowan]] *[[Nishihara, Okinawa|Nishihara]]<ref name="n" />
==Transportation== The city is served by [[Naha Airport]] and the [[Okinawa Expressway]]. There are plans for the [[Yui Rail]] to be extended to Urasoe.
==History== Urasoe was the original capital of the Okinawan kingdom of [[Chūzan]] for several centuries until it was supplanted by [[Shuri, Okinawa|Shuri]] in the late 14th or early 15th century. [[Shunten]] (1166 – 1237), the first known king of the Chuzan Kingdom, located in the central region of the island of Okinawa, ruled from Urasoe, as did his son and grandson.<ref name="d"/><ref name="e"/> For much of the 14th century, [[Urasoe Castle]] was the largest on the island of Okinawa. The castle now contains the remains of several kings of the [[Ryukyu Kingdom]].<ref name="e"/><ref name="pearson"/>
Urasoe was completely razed during the [[Battle of Okinawa]] in 1945 at the end of [[World War II]]. 45% of the population, 4,117 residents, died during the battle. The village office of Urasoe was re-established in 1946 to conduct basic administrative functions, settle refugees returning to the village, and restore agricultural land.<ref name="n" /> The village saw a significant increase in U.S. military presence in 1950 in the western coast of the village, which eventually became [[Camp Kinser]]. The population of Urasoe rapidly from 1956, and the city became a bedroom community of Naha in this period.<ref name="guide"/><ref name="n"/><ref name="e"/> Urasoe was elevated to city status on July 1, 1970.<ref name="guide"/>
==Economy== The beer company [[Orion Breweries]] has its headquarters in Urasoe.<ref name="orion"/>
==Notable residents== Urasoe is the hometown of Japanese actress, musician and former idol [[Yukie Nakama]].<ref name="nakama"/>

[[Erasmus University Rotterdam]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy]]) |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Historian]] · [[Political science|Political scientist]] · [[Research|Researcher]] · [[Author]] · [[Columnist]] · [[Professor]] |signature = |website = }} '''Uriël "Uri" Rosenthal''' (born 19 July 1945) is a retired [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD). Rosenthal a [[Political science|political scientist]] by occupation, was elected as a [[Senate (Netherlands)|Member of the Senate]] on 8 June 1999 after the Senate election of 1999. On 5 May 2005 he was selected as the [[parliamentary leader]] of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] in the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]]. Following the [[Dutch general election, 2010|election of 2010]] Rosenthal was asked to become [[List of Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] in the [[First Rutte cabinet|Cabinet Rutte–Verhagen]] Rosenthal accepted and resigned as [[parliamentary leader]] in the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] and a [[Senate (Netherlands)|Member of the Senate]] the same day he took office as the new [[List of Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] on 14 October 2010 serving until 5 November 2012. A [[professor]] of [[political science]] and [[public administration]] by occupation, he taught from 1980 until 2010 at the [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]] and [[Leiden University]]. ==Early life== Uriël Rosenthal was born on 19 July 1945 in [[Montreux]], [[Switzerland]] to [[Jews|Jewish]] parents who during [[World War II]] fled the [[Netherlands]] from the [[History of the Netherlands (1939–1945)|German occupation of the Netherlands]]. The returned to the Netherlands shortly after the war ended. After attending school in [[The Hague]] he went to study [[political science]] at the [[University of Amsterdam]] where he obtained a [[Bachelor of Social Science]] and a [[Master of Social Science]] in 1970. In 1978 he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in [[social sciences]] at the [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]]. In 1980 he became a [[professor]] of [[political science]] and [[public administration]] at the [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]]. From 1987 until 2011 he was a [[professor]] of [[public administration]] at the [[Leiden University]]. ==Politics== He was elected [[Senate of the Netherlands|Member of the Senate]] as a member of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and took office on 8 June 1999. He became the [[Parliamentary group leader|Parliamentary leader]] in the [[Senate of the Netherlands|Senate]] on 5 May 2005. On 12 June 2010 Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Beatrix]] nominated Rosenthal as first [[formateur|informateur]] in the [[2010 Dutch cabinet formation]].{{nl icon}} [http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/verkiezingen2010/article2562757.ece/VVDer_Uri_Rosenthal_informateur VVD'er Uri Rosenthal informateur] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421053157/http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/verkiezingen2010/article2562757.ece/VVDer_Uri_Rosenthal_informateur |date=2012-04-21 }}, NRC, 12 June 2010 On 26 June the Queen replaced Rosenthal with [[Herman Tjeenk Willink]], the [[Council of State of the Netherlands|Vice President of the Council of State]] as the new informateur.{{en icon}} [http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/queen-appoints-new-coalition-negotiator Queen appoints new coalition negotiator], Radio Netherlands Worldwide, 26 June 2010 On 5 July he became [[formateur|informateur]] a second time together with [[Jacques Wallage]] of the [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]].{{en icon}} [http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/dutch-coalition-talks-continue-behind-closed-doors Dutch coalition talks continue behind closed doors] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709074056/http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/dutch-coalition-talks-continue-behind-closed-doors |date=2010-07-09 }}, Radio Netherlands Worldwide, 6 July 2010 But on 21 July the Queen again replaced him and [[Jacques Wallage|Wallage]] with [[Minister of State (Netherlands)|Minister of State]] and former [[Prime Minister of the Netherlands|Prime Minister]] [[Ruud Lubbers]]. On 28 September the negotiations were finished. A coalition agreement was reached between [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] to form a minority coalition, supported by the [[Party for Freedom]] to obtain a majority. [[Formateur]] [[Mark Rutte]] asked Rosenthal as the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] in the new [[First Rutte cabinet|cabinet]]. Because a member of the [[States-General of the Netherlands]] can not serve in the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] he resigned as a [[Senate of the Netherlands|Member of the Senate]] and [[Parliamentary group leader|Parliamentary leader]] on 14 October 2010, the same day he took office as the new [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]].{{nl icon}} [http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2629567.ece/Uri_Rosenthal_is_beoogd_minister_Buitenlandse_Zaken Uri Rosenthal is beoogd minister Buitenlandse Zaken] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720132351/http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2629567.ece/Uri_Rosenthal_is_beoogd_minister_Buitenlandse_Zaken |date=2011-07-20 }}, NRC, 8 October 2010 As of 1 March 2013, Rosenthal is chairman of the Policy Advisory Council on Science and Technology (AWT). He has been nominated by the Dutch Government to serve as the Special Envoy for the fourth [[Global Conference on CyberSpace|International Cyberspace Conference]] to be held in 2015.{{cite web|title=Netherlands to host international Cyberspace Conference in 2015|url=http://www.government.nl/news/2013/10/18/netherlands-to-host-international-cyberspace-conference-in-2015.html|publisher=Government of the Netherlands|accessdate=20 March 2014}} ==Family== He has been married since 4 January 1973. He lives in [[Rotterdam]] with his wife, Dinah, and their two children. Dinah Rosenthal is an [[Israel]]i native, originally from [[Haifa]]. Two of Rosenthal's sisters live in Israel.{{nl icon}} [http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2011/09/29/d66-en-pvv-eisen-uitleg-over-blokkade-eu-standpunt-israel/ D66 en PvdA eisen uitleg over Nederlandse blokkade EU-standpunt Israël], NRC, 29 September 2011{{Cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/uri-rosenthal-crisis-professor-foreign-minister |title=Uri Rosenthal: from crisis professor to Foreign Minister |access-date=2013-12-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214104109/http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/uri-rosenthal-crisis-professor-foreign-minister |archive-date=2013-12-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Decorations== {| class="wikitable" style="width:60%;" |- style="background:#ccf; text-align:center;" | colspan=5 |'''Honours''' |- ! style="width:80px;"| Ribbon bar !!
